content: The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" may be cited as the Act. It includes an FMAP adjustment for affected jurisdictions equivalent to compact migrant expenditures. The "Compact Impact Relief Act of 2016" increases the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on estimated compact migrant expenditures. The chief executive official must submit expenditure estimates to the Secretary of the Interior for review before each calendar quarter. The Secretary of the Interior reviews and adjusts the chief executive official's estimation of compact migrant expenditures before each calendar quarter. The Secretary of Health and Human Services then estimates the increase in FMAP needed for each affected jurisdiction to receive more federal payments. The Secretary of Health and Human Services estimates the increase in FMAP needed for affected jurisdictions to receive more federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act, ensuring payments do not exceed set limitations. The Secretary of Health and Human Services notifies chief executive officials of affected jurisdictions about increases in FMAP under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Chief executive officials must submit accounting reports to the Secretary of the Interior for payment adjustments. The chief executive official of an affected jurisdiction must submit an accounting of compact migrant expenditures to the Secretary of the Interior for review and adjustments, following an increase in FMAP. The Secretary of the Interior will then provide a final accounting to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services reviews and adjusts the increase in FMAP for affected jurisdictions, ensuring that Federal payments under title XIX of the Social Security Act align with the final accounting of compact migrant expenditures submitted. The Secretary of Health and Human Services adjusts the FMAP for affected jurisdictions based on final accounting of migrant expenditures, with limitations to prevent exceeding 100 percent. The FMAP increase for affected jurisdictions is capped at 100 percent, and compact migrant expenditures are not considered medical assistance under title XIX of the Social Security Act. Definitions for "affected jurisdiction" and "compact migrant expenditures" are provided in this section. The term "compact migrant expenditures" refers to non-Federal funds spent by affected jurisdictions on healthcare for qualified nonimmigrants, excluding payments made under a State plan or from other Federal sources. The term "FMAP" refers to the Federal medical assistance percentage under the Social Security Act, and a conforming amendment is made to section 1905(b) of the Act. SEC. 3. PAYMENTS RELATING TO ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION OF CITIZENS OF FREELY ASSOCIATED STATES. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include educating alien children from Freely Associated States and payments for eligible federally connected children residing in the United States. Amendment to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 includes providing additional funding for eligible federally connected children who are citizens of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, or the Republic of Palau. This involves multiplying the number of these children by a factor of 1.25. Additional funding of $10,000,000 annually is authorized for federally connected children under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. SEC. 4 amends the Housing and Community Development Act to give preference to US citizens or nationals over aliens for housing financial assistance in Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands. SEC. 5 calls for an independent assessment of the strategic relationship between the US and the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau. The Secretary of State is required to seek an agreement with an eligible organization to assess the strategic importance of the relationship between the United States and the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Republic of Palau. This assessment includes evaluating the relationships as part of the Asia-Pacific re-balance, assessing the capabilities of US Government agencies in administering the Compact of Free Association. The curr_chunk focuses on assessing the capabilities and shortcomings of US Government agencies in administering the Compacts of Free Association with the Marshall Islands, Micronesia, and Palau, along with recommendations for improvements and future administration. It also includes any other relevant matters determined by the eligible organization. The eligible organization entering into an agreement under this section must submit a report to the Secretary of State within one year of the Act's enactment. The report should include the assessment required under subsection (a), matters specified in subsection (b), and any other relevant issues deemed appropriate by the Secretary. The report must be in unclassified form, with the option of a classified annex if necessary. The eligible organization can obtain official data from US departments or agencies to fulfill the agreement.
